Text: That'd be *cite*, not *site*.
@TRiG, Thanks. Edited to correct.
Arrrrrgh! You changed *both* of them!
I think migrating the best questions is a good idea.  But wouldn't we need Stack Echange resouces to do this?  @ben-collins, you work for SE right?  Any input on migrating?
Where did he mention that?

I agree and I think it is happening again. Just going through the review queue, questions are being flagged as opinion based or too broad but could have easily gathered some great answers. There is no concrete right answer for them but an answer could be given. I am noticing that a few users are closing questions generally based on the rep of the person as well. Similar questions get through if the person has contributed a bit more on the site and as soon as one person presses close, others tend to follow. Since most people come from SO I think that their moderation rules are following.

Honestly, we need more down votes to help *guide* the bad posts toward higher quality. It's truly a shark tank, and I'm still going to be inclined to down vote or close if it is a really lame, clearly-no-research type of question.

@jdero: I understand you at 100% but... The problem is, that people ("askers") come from outside, ask 1 or 2 questions without thinking about its "quality". Or they get some answers and they will maybe come back, or their questions will be closed as "poor" and they will never come back. From their point of view, theirs questions are "important" & "interesting" because it's important & interesting for them. They don't see this web as some kind of "wiki for entrepreneurs"... And thus, we have the "egg/hen" problem. Without visitors, no site development...
"*Why isn't there more information about taxes easily available to startup founders?*" - because tax is so complicated that it's impossible to concisely state anything correctly.

Ah, yes. I believe I have the same opinion. I still don't get why there isn't a class in standard public education dedicated to taxes (a required course for high school graduation) since we *all* pay taxes.

I can see your point, but I also see value in keeping around some more general "beginner" questions. While it is possible to find this information by digging through various sites, I tend to trust highly-upvoted answers on SE more than a lot of things I read on the internet. I notice the same argument a lot on StackOverflow with questions that are closed as off-topic that have tens of thousands of views, hundreds of up-votes and appear at the top of search results. Those are often quite useful, and would really prefer that they could just be tagged appropriately and kept around.
I guess what I'm really looking for is more like a wiki that is moderated in the style of the SE sites.
That information may be valuable, but like you said it's more of a wiki than Q/A. Those questions may get a bunch of views, but I don't think they're good questions

I'm curious, is there any way to manually move questions to the community-wiki status? As I've mentioned elsewhere, I think this type of question could be valuable if it was handled appropriately. Maybe it could be tagged as "wiki", and the normal rules for "good" questions could be relaxed. I suspect that having a reliable source of background information readily available and editable on the site would not only bring new users, but also serve as a springboard for more focused questions that fit the normal Q/A format.
I thought there was. It only seems to be available for answers currently. Community wiki posts are still Q/A though.
That's exactly what I mean. I see this close reason as being used for eliminating those questions that are intended to compile a list or promote a discussion.
@connor yeah I thought you were thinking the same as me from your commentary on the question that brought this up

I'm still trying to figure out how subjective is too subjective myself. On one hand we want don't want to eliminate too many questions, on the other we don't want to fall apart like the last site for having too much junk. I mean for this close reason to be just used for questions that explicitly ask to compile a list or generate a discussion. From there we can start generating a clearer picture of the line between on and off-topic, but I think these types are definite off-topic.

Building off of that I just saw this question, which I think is a great example of something that is subjective but not too much so: http://startups.stackexchange.com/questions/184/is-employee-value-derived-from-their-equity

@connor That is a good example. I think the specificity helps, too. Yeah, I'm not really trying to argue one way or the other for what "too subjective" means, so much as raise the matter that we, as early users, are more or less tasked with coming to a comfortable definition of what we think it should mean. But regardless of how we define it, I certainly concur that there will be times when we'll need a flag reason for this.
Cool. Now how do we get that done? Is there a way to get the attention of the community managers?

Just a thought and I'm not completely sure how strongly I believe this, but it kind of seems like subjective requests meant to "benefit the populous" are inappropriate, whereas more specific cases aren't. Like if someone says "what free software is there for startups?" that's a little too broad to be productive. But if someone says, "I'm starting a store and I don't need anything too spectacular but I'd like to have a website, what cheap tools are there to help me with that?" I think that could benefit from people's experience in the field.
So perhaps this flag could represent a mix of too subjective and too broad?

@connor I think through Meta posts like this. I mean, it's clearly not our position--you and me--to make these decisions. I think we just need your post here to gain some more attention, and for that we don't have many options other than to just hope more people come on this evening and vote it up.

Benefit the populous is a good point. I think the hypothetical questions that are intended to help future users make giving them a good answer impossible. Your latter version is definitely better, but I still feel it's borderline. It's tough for me to decide right now.
As I understand it, it is mostly up to us (meaning the larger community). I'm just not sure where the community managers are lurking
"it may get out of hand" - nice.

To expand on that, I think we should use the common english name of the country and use a shorter name when possible. For example, united-states instead of united-states-of-america and china instead of peoples-republic-of-china. As long as they're understandable, we should be ok.
@connor yeah sounds good to me.
I completely agree. I was only considering the best, canonical answers. Just to help give the site some good content.
I definitely agree that [tag:usa] should be a synonym for [tag:united-states] however there is only one of those that is the primary and that's what I'm talking about.
I agree. I'm responsible for some of those edits.
Completely agree: http://meta.startups.stackexchange.com/a/34/92
possible duplicate of [Tagging guidelines - country names](http://meta.startups.stackexchange.com/questions/31/tagging-guidelines-country-names)

@Daniel I hadn't seen that one originally, but I agree that they draw the same conclusion. However, I'm inclined to leave mine open too since that one is meant to set a standard practice and mine addresses a particular case; a single tag synonym is a very different matter than setting up a scheme of countries as tags, even if the scheme of countries would, by definition, lead to the synonym being put in place. Mine's more a short-term solution that could be implemented in seconds, compared to that which is a longer-term, systematic solution.
@MatthewHaugen I understand your reasoning and support it. I did also miss, that Awal Garg was referencing the other post too. Therefore I retracted my close vote
I fully support this - great post Matt.

There is an issue with experts in the Startup space that make me worry about the validity of this site. I already work far too much on my startup, I have staff, office, growth (getting close to a large investment round, fingers crossed) etc but I find it difficult to put in hours here. People I know that founded very well known startups, millions in funding etc, just won't have the time here, hence it seems once reaching a certain stage, there might be drop off of experienced entrepreneurs past a point. Programmers is always different because you can have superstar programmers who work 9-5

We have a few weeks to think about there is no guarantee that the Community Team will choose the same people we vote on but we can at least share our preferences to let them have an additional metric to make the decision on.
good luck to all candidates :) Hope we get the best of the best!
Its been quite a while, I think mods should have been announced by now.

@AwalGarg I would have thought so two - two weeks public beta now. However we have low enough activity that it isn't to bad - only benefit to our low activity which we do need to fix (questions/per day really is our only metric I don't like right now)
Vote was 7-6-6-2 at time of closing. connor, nick/jdero, matthew.
I'll second that
Thanks for the nomination, Nick. I'd definitely be willing to moderate this site. I can't edit this post to add my approval though.
@connor good luck
Connor has my vote
@Adam you can of course vote for multiple - most sites get 2-3 PT moderators

"*something this community should be nothing about*" - really?  Freelancers are one-man businesses that require financing, marketing, accounts management... if incorporated, they face the same filing and documentation challenges as any other business, they need to employ themselves (resulting in all the same employment law issues), etc.  Sure, I understand that there is a difference, but when a freelancer decides to employ his wife to do the accounts and takes on a contractor to assist with workload... doesn't it become something more? All I'm saying is that it's a grey area.
I agree that there is some significant greyness there... @Adam do you have an idea of how we can clearly and consistently categorize as one or another?

@eggyal - there is cross over but clearly any freelancing questions should be asked on http://freelancing.stackexchange.com/. As per the description of the site itself: "Q&A site for entrepreneurs faced with delivering a new product or service under conditions of significant uncertainty" Freelancing doesn't fall in this category. Freelancing doesn't really deliver a product or service with significant uncertainty. They get a job, deliver a product or service and get paid. Start-ups deliver a product or service, generally not widely done before with very varying returns.

Just because a question would be on-topic on another SE site does not make it off-topic here, so the existence of [freelancing.se] is pretty much irrelevant to this discussion.  If you don't believe that freelancing delivers "a service with significant uncertainty" then I think you may want to speak to a few more freelancers: marketing themselves, finding clients, learning new skills, identifying the right opportunities - all leave freelancers in precarious, uncertain positions from one job to the next.
I know there is uncertainty but its predictable uncertainty. My main concern comes from what a startup is actually defined as: http://www.paulgraham.com/growth.html

Freelancing isn't a highly scalable venture, its time for money. If its not a startup or from someone working or founding a startup, this site may as well be called Small Business. As per the Area51 discussion, it seemed more popular to limit it to tech startups than to expand to small business in general. http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/questions/14770/proposal-to-increase-the-scope-from-startup-business-to-business-or-some-oth

Every service business is "time for money".  Take someone like [PA Consulting](http://www.paconsulting.com/): all they sell is their time, yet anyone starting up a consulting firm of that sort would probably find their questions on-topic here.  And I'm not sure that questions should be off-topic just because a person's business model is not "scalable".
Start-ups aren't a "time for money" business model, which just adds to the point I'm making.
So if, together with some friends, I start a consulting business (along the same lines as PA Consulting)... you wouldn't consider that to be a startup business?!
I wouldn't consider that a start-up as defined here: http://www.paulgraham.com/growth.html

I don't see anything in that article that precludes my hypothetical consultancy business from being a startup.  Look at the historical growth rates of many such consultancy businesses, including those that I have mentioned.

One example I am using is: http://startups.stackexchange.com/questions/222/how-should-i-start-a-freelance-web-app-development-business

It was flagged as too-broad but its not too-broad, its completely off-topic. This is showing that people think the question is related but not in good Q&A format. People should not be answering and mention its off-topic.
Jdreo has my vote as well

Hi, thank you for the nomination. I guess I should just add a little bit. Clearly, I wasn't the greatest programmer, and had little to offer in my 1 year of activity on SO. I followed onstartups for a while, and actively helped to bring startups back, and really want to dedicate myself to this community to make it something great.
I want to see this guy as one of the moderator... reason - he is friendly, helpful, has nice communication skills and obviously one of the lead users on Startups.SE (also active)
Vote was 7-6-6-2 at time of closing.
I know that something went wrong with Softwarerecs.SE but you will make a good mod on Startups.

@Mr.Alien I don't think anything per se went wrong with the moderator selection there; our Moderators are pretty good :) I think though that most likely the reason I wasn't on the shortlist was lack of history of activity - sure I've been intermittently active on StackOverflow as needed basically but now; SR shows what I can do - 44% of first post review are mine, and I have >100 accepted flags; it shows that I understand moderation whereas before I was a relatively new user with very limited community moderation history.
As an SR mod, I can vouch for Nick - he's been a driving force on SR, and seems to know quite a bit about SE and the system itself.
@Undo Thanks. SR is really where I cut my teeth on the SE system after my occasional uses of SO.

*General* business questions will be just as applicable to the tech industry as they are to other industry sectors.  So, if I've understood correctly, your proposal is to exclude questions that are *specifically* about a non-tech sector.  So far, they're relatively few and far between.  What would be the problem with allowing such questions?

I said they are relevant but if we have a large user base who are small business owners, then they will ask general business questions, further obscuring tech startup related questions, then it attracts more small business and the cycle repeats. Then why not just change it to small business. I just don't think this community has its niche defined thoroughly enough yet.

I think there are two proposals here: restrict to **startups** (i.e. refuse questions that are pertinent only to more established businesses); and restrict to the **tech industry** (i.e. refuse questions that are pertinent only to non-tech industries).  Whilst I support the former proposal (but foresee considerable difficulty in defining exactly when a startup becomes "too mature"), I don't really see any reason for the latter - isn't it just a case of *tagging* questions in such a way that those interested in only one particular industry can filter the site accordingly?

Before answering what *type* of startups, do you think there is any value to looking at [how to define a startup](http://meta.startups.stackexchange.com/questions/6/what-is-a-startup)? Adam seems to be under the impression it is defined as 'small business', but many of the questions on the site seem to ask about the stage prior to having any business at all. May be a discussion worth having. Hope this helps!

Start-ups are a niche of small business. Also I don't mind what stage a startup is in, either in its growth phase or thinking about staring one, I think any stage is good for the site. The point is small business isn't a startup yet we are getting questions purely about small businesses on here that don't relate to startups. However startups don't have to be tech related but they tend to be. I believe that actually focussing on Tech Startups is going to clarify the site and stop its tendency to move towards small business. I hope that makes sense.
RamenForRevenue :) I joke.
I don't really have any good thoughts yet.

Curious - who is we? Who made the decision to extend? I think the quality of the majority of the questions here are great. Like the guy who asked about scrum-styled workflow mgmt but not necessarily for software... As time passes I think we'll get more and more breadth (as opposed to depth) of questions.

@jdero I would assume 'we' to be the Stack Overflow Community Team; atleast Robert is part of that and that is the group that *would* decide that. I also think the questions and answers are by and large of quite good quality. That being said I definitely see the lack of breadth being a problem.
I see - I'm curious - is there an algorithm that gives us a score? Or is it somewhat of a general observation? Probably a mix of both?

I *believe* that the CT (Community Team) have more data/metrics they use as well as human centred decision making. From the public area 51 stats we look good in some ways; high answered percentage, okay answers per question, low views but that doesn't usually pick up until *at least* a couple months in the *public beta*. Concerning stat is the questions per day at this point - 10/day: during the private beta it is really good to have it if anything more like 20+ to get off to a good start. (do note this is highly unofficial analysis)

Robert, is there any way that we (or SE) can apply some gentle pressure to [those who committed to the Area 51 proposal](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/62811?phase=commitment) but who have not yet shown up here?

Just to put it out there, questions per day is averaging at 7 right now. The average is also declining. We have to fight this <3 ... I just feel like I'm the only one on the entire site sometimes, and don't want to just ask a ton of consecutive questions. I have a lot to ask, I just don't want to look like an attention hoodlum.

I wouldn't worry about asking too much or too much into the average right now. I'd expect the private beta numbers to below the 15/day threshold. Also, if you have good questions, ask them. It helps to have good questions to define the scope of the site and show SE that good questions are coming out of this beta.
Well, this private beta launched right as I went on vacation. I managed to ask 1 and answer 2 questions before taking a 10-day trip. Looks like it's time to polish a few more questions
@jdero yeah I know... sorry. I was away for the weekend (well since Thursday really) so didn't get more than a couple review actions done

I think that focus is still too narrow. Not all businesses aim for an IPO, nor do all that do get there. And many questions are not only related to small businesses either. Thus I would propose a much broader focus such as `running a business` in general (see my answer below).
If StackOverflow was filled with a whole group of beginner programmers, how do you think that site would have gone?

@Adam it wasn't. And neither is this. We all know something or the other... And btw, even Jon Skeet wasn't present at the very beginning, he joined later. We do have people who know things, and that is why questions are being answered. There are many questions which are related to maintaining a startup, just that the other ones are much abundant.

You're missing the point. Start-ups are NOT generally defined as a business about to start-up, that is called usually called a small or micro business. Start-ups are a different type of business altogether. If you wanted a small business forum there are plenty around. More experienced start up owners aren't going to come here for people literally just about to start up. And if you don't have more experienced founders then you are literally going to have new business founders answering questions they only think they know the answer to but have not actually gone through.
@Adam exactly... and other than inviting people, we can't do anything. But we do have some great men here, and we are improving since day one, and we will keep improving. That's all I meant to say.

But it _is_ filled with beginners. That's the very definition of a startup: a business that is in the beginning! And if we focus on startups only, this will always be the case. As soon as anyone got any insightful answers, they have no startup anymore and thus no interest in a startup community. Startups have the most questions, but not the answers. Alas we need to change the name in order to attract and maintain people who got some answers!
What types of startup questions are you thinking of that aren't 'business' questions?
When startup questions are business questions, I'm fine with that, but I don't want this site to become a business site not associated with startups.
I don't mean having premaking tags for all countries but for any countries that are required to use those guidelines.
+1 I very much like Dave McClure's definition; whilst a little bit tongue-in-cheek, it's actually very concise and surprisingly well aligned with my own sense of what defines a "startup".
@eggyal yes, that definition is my fav too as it, for one, defines startup and business clearly apart and two, nicely captures the excitement and risk of startups.
"Conception to Exit" might work better given your first point above.

I fully agree with everything you say. We need people who have the same problems and we need people who have answers to some of the problems. And I think we should just consider business in general as a viable option.
You have four upvotes. Not everybody is in disagreement with you.

I would even argue that focusing on small business is to focused. The question is: Who has the same problems and who has answers to these questions. I think the answer is everyone in the process of leading a business.
@roesslerj: So then the site becomes a "Business Leadership" SE?  I think that's some way from what the original Area51 proposal envisaged...

Thats true, but the other option seems to be to have this site die a lonely death. And honestly: I have seen lots of interesting talks and gotten lots of very helpful advice for/about startups. But those were all from people that were not running startups anymore, because they grew out of that phase.
Regarding @Adam's comment on AwalGarg's answer: I agree and I see this as a way to fill the site with non-beginners in business.
Awesome answer! Loved since the very first sentence. Thanks.
@Math: Thanks for your positive reinforcement ;-)
I agree, although I would point out that knowledge and moderation are not always required to be combined.

Thanks! I'd be honored. I'd love to work with everyone to build this site up. I know there's some talk on the featured posts on whether this SE is actually going anywhere, but I definitely think we can resolve that and make it a resource to entrepreneurs everywhere.
Both this and the area51 proposal for  a site on sex questions really could use some anonymous method. Like hide name and profile link but include rep range (ie like just say <500 or >500 or 1k etc.
I agree that this is a great idea, but I think stack exchange has shot down this idea a few times already. :(

_"If your question is about Strategies for successfully bringing a product or service to market"_ is ontopic... I am also assuming this is about a particular product or service, and not a general question, since it will be too broad then and over in one go! But then, you say _"How can I market this?"_ is offtopic... I think they are both quite related... any clarifications on that?
I vote for "Starting _and running_ a small business..." (and I would even omit "small"), but otherwise I'm in favor. Of the exclusions in any case...

@AwalGarg These types of sites always seem to attract question like "How do I get people to use my website <link>". "I have this idea... will it work?" Under the category of "general brainstorming", folks soliciting broad ideas for a product or marketing strategy go well beyond this type of Q&A. But that does ***not*** preclude very *specific* questions you may have encountered in marketing your product or service. That's not what I meant in that *general brainstorming* clause.

You might want to include a point specifically addressing ads. I know it's discussed elsewhere, but I see you deleted a question just today wherein someone was blatantly spamming about their PR business, and I would never have expected that sort of behavior in a *private* beta. The more we can do to combat those in the future, the better.

@RobertCartaino Thanks for the clarification. I agree to that. And also, I agree to what \@roesslerj said, so it would be great if you incorporate that... I am a bit busy now, and will post a complete answer later.

I think you should allow for asking questions about how to market successfully.  Keep it strategy focused, of course, but definitely allow "I'm here, but no idea where to go next with marketing"  Entrepreneurs are often and foremost technicians and not sales experts and this is one of the most often asked question I get as I help small businesses build their websites and online presence.

I don't see why it would be problematic if they only allowed it from users with 500+ rep, and then included your rep range in the post, and still had the same provisions and restrictions as you would normally, except a hidden link to the actual profile.

The creator of Bright Journey [mentioned](http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/a/13096) it during a discussion on this site's Area51 proposal, so I don't see how "*neither of us knows the other exact*"?
Well that makes this awkward. Thanks for the link.

@eggyal In reading your link (apologies for the delay), this is only a reference to onstartups. I'm talking about this new startups community, and furthermore the knowledge of brightjourney in general by current startups.se folk. Sad to read that post, but with their help we will stand a better chance at succeeding.

I'm not sure whether we're looking at the same post?  I'm referring to Hopstream's answer, beginning "Being frustrated with how the Answers.Onstartups knowledge was closed, we re-created the community over the last month: Bright Journey"?
What does that have to do with our awareness of their presence? Clearly they came from onstartups, and therefore recognize the SE community, but that's not really what I was posting about.
I'm just saying that the existence of Bright Journey was disclosed to "us" during a discussion on the Area51 proposal.
Agreed, according to the help docs for this site at http://startups.stackexchange.com/help/on-topic, yes these are on topic.
Thanks guys :) I hope we will further create more, better, and quality content. And congratulations to all! And when are we getting our pro tem mods btw?

@AwalGarg Soon, this is the point where we _really_ start looking for folks that want to help lead the community, Grace Note will probably begin the selection process within a week or two. Anyone interested should [head over here](http://meta.startups.stackexchange.com/questions/38/nominate-pro-tempore-moderators-to-help-guide-the-site-through-beta) and throw their hat in, soon. We do look at possible candidates based on their activity and interactions alone, but make sure you chime in there just to be safe if interested.
I think I got accomplished  what I wanted in the fact this meta post is approaching 100 views. It's just good to be aware of each other :)
Stupid question--where do we vote for tag synonyms, anyway? It isn't on review and I don't see it anywhere on the tag page itself.
is there an up arrow here: http://startups.stackexchange.com/tags/united-states/synonyms ?
although I'm curious if there's a page to see all of the running votes. That would be nice.

Ah, I see. Thanks. Yeah, that would be useful. Although I suppose the rush of tag synonyms probably tends to slow down as the site gets established, so it probably hasn't been a high priority UI-wise. Maybe the idea is that people make posts on meta (case in point)?

hmmph I apparently haven't been answering my southern neighbours questions enough - at least the requirement is 4 score on the tag (not total rep) and I don't have that yet - I have more rep on Sri-Lanka than I do on united-states!

Off-hand I can't think of any other states/provinces that have a duplication with a country name. hmmm I do not like applying -state to everyone state (and then would we want to append -province to every province). I think at this point maybe leave it and see what happens. Basically I'm copping out because I can't think of a good solution.

@NickWilde works for me. I'm not sure what the actual chances of anyone needing to refer to the country actually are. Admittedly I'm not the most informed about the country, but I don't get the impression it's teeming with the sorts of innovation we generally discuss here. I just figured it should be brought up before someone *does* attempt to refer to the country and gets some wildly inaccurate answers. But hopefully the tag wiki will handle that before it happens anyway.

I agree that georgia-country would be a fine fit (and would be better than doing georgia-state - it makes more sense to add the modifier to the less frequently used one tag).
 But I don't see a reason to add the tag until someone needs to use it (though having already discussed it when/if that time comes will be helpful).
Not an answer as I'm still thinking... app-development doesn't to me specify mobile nor does mobile-apps specify the development of apps; it could just as easily mean to me support or etc.

That's a good point. I suppose you could use another tag in addition to complement mobile-apps if you want to specify that you are a support company. Like how if you're a california llc, you'd use california and llc instead of california-llc

exactly my thought. In which case app-development should still be burninated and replaced with `development` or `support` or whatever if applicable.If that is so I'm in favour of the burnination of app-development.
Since there doesn't seem to be any opposition, I went ahead and retagged those five questions.

+1 - though I would have liked to see some more activity from other users rather than just lack of opposition. (I think right thing to do and fine to go ahead but I'm glaring at those not being active on meta)
Well it's also up to those who review the edits. I've lost my edit priviledge since we went public
me to (sob)... soon I'll get it back though

Agree. Quora is a much better source of startup-related answers than what I've seen here and on other SE sites. You often see answers from actual VCs and angel investors ([David Rose's answers](https://www.quora.com/David-S-Rose) are remarkable); AFAIK, none of those folks are active here.

Might be worth noting that it appears you might be bit bias on the topic; meaning it appears your current activity on Quora is: Questions-61, Answers-296, Posts-3, Edits-1739; but on SE-Startups Main & Meta, aside from the comment above, you've had zero activity.

Correct, I've just learned about SE-Startups today. I used to be active on answers.onstartups.com. Nevertheless, with all due respect for the [top users here](https://startups.stackexchange.com/users?tab=Reputation&filter=all), I don't see any of the major angel investors from Quora, and their answers have often provided unique insight into the fundraising part of startup life. Same goes for famous founders.

@DanDascalescu: Unique insight only go so far for the average startup, and maybe I'm biased, but I'm not impressed with Quora's free for all approach; as you know, if SE took that approach, OnStartups would still be on SE, and I personally am very happy with the mods & community of Startups-SE. Welcome back... :-)

To each their own; while the quality of technical answers on Quora is far behind SO, the frustration I've experienced with the general "fist in your face" attitude on SE (nonsensical close votes, deletionists, overzealous moderators [etc](https://pinboard.in/search/u:dandv?query=against+stackexchange).) has pushed me to Quora many times.
can you point out why down vote ?
Thanks for suggestion but [tag:field-sales] tag is more suitable.
inside sales talks about approach like by phone , online etc.where field-sales talks about versicle of sales.don't mix both .
it's not convincing to me.

@Rudra: Yes, I know; my point was to create two tags, one for each term - and apply them to real existing questions. Are you going to post examples of teal existing questions that are on the site that should have field-sales as a tag? If not, your questions appears to be speculative and there's no need to add the tag. Also, just in case it's not clear, if you earn enough rep, you can add tags yourself.

Unfortunately, though, [chat] is pretty quiet as-is, and I fear that filtering down that audience by geography could have two undesirable effects: one, each room would be all the quieter (although that's really just a matter of waiting until we have enough users, and perhaps people would talk more with others in their area), and two, it might make people feel left out who weren't in a covered area. I would hate to see the only contributor from some part of the world feel left out or like they weren't welcome in the community. We really don't want "cliques" forming, in other words.

Those shouldn't, of course, be taken as "this is impossible and we shouldn't do it," they're just things to overcome. I do think it's an intriguing idea, and worth exploring, I just don't want our community-building efforts to leave anyone out.

Re: migrated questions, I think that limitation *is* enforced by the system, but diamond moderators get to bypass it manually. Non-moderators cannot migrate a question *to* [main] (except from meta), nor can they migrate a question *from* [main] (except to meta). When we graduate, a few sites will be populated into our list of user-votable outbound ones, and we'll show up on a few other sites'.

Historically one on the largest bottlenecks in sites becoming non-beta sites beyond the basics such as traffic and community was that SE appears to have had a hard time rolling out the visual building blocks of a site; believe that they're working on this, but sites like Salesforce-SE met the requirements (per SE) to become a non-beta site, and even after that it was still 6-12 months until the site finally rolled out.

Denis, I think we're going to have to agree to disagree on a couple of points: 
1) Whether 5,000 constitutes 'bulk',
2) Whether personalising unsolicited bulk emails overrides the necessity of getting consent,
3) Whether the fact that people do it every day makes it ok,
4) Whether spam email is legal in all jurisdictions; I've repeatedly cited the particular law which makes the practise you describe above illegal here in the UK, and don't see much point in repeating myself again; if you want to ignore the law then that's up to you - if you're outside the UK then it's irrelevant to you anyway.

A lawyer's analysis of the relevant law: http://www.lawdonut.co.uk/law/sales-and-marketing/marketing-and-advertising/your-email-marketing-and-anti-spam-law Basically, B2B 'cold email' can be legal ("You can ‘cold email’ an unsolicited, direct marketing email to a corporate subscriber, but be careful.") but B2C is not ("This is permitted if the email is work-related (eg promoting office furniture to a facilities manager) but not if it is personal (eg promoting family holidays to the sales team at a recruitment company).").

Thanks for starting this discussion Denis. I've marked it as featured so it shows up on the main site. I don't think many folks browse the meta.

I think the idea behind the featured topics was quality out of quantity, but special topic questions ended up being worse on average. I think it's worked on other sites though, so I'm open to trying it again with tweaks.

For what (little, extremely little) it's worth, I do think monthly topics increased the volume of good questions. They just also proportionately (or more) increased the volume of bad ones. But if we had a good metric by which to judge a "bad" question (since I don't think the only problem here is what's on- or off-topic for the site), we might be able to slow, or at least kill, the latter. Not sure where exactly I'm going with this, except that I agree with @connor: I'm open to trying improvements.

@MatthewHaugen: I've honestly no idea how well it worked, but I vividly recollect a period where we were getting swamped by _terrible_ product market fit and pivoting questions. :D Also, I seem to remember the questions lacked depth. By this I mean you could usually feel they weren't genuine; they lacked that screaming cry for help touch that makes some of the better questions instantly picture what the asker is going through.
I think this could have the dual benefit of improving quantity and refining our scope as we add to it.

Chat and Meta becoming ghost towns is not particularly problematic. We have quite a few sites on the network that get very little to no consistent activity on either of those platforms but are still able to successfully run. The major problem here is the lack of community moderation, and a build-up of very low quality content and even spam on the main site. Lack of Meta participation only reinforces the conclusion that the site is lacking the necessary interest to moderate and maintain.

@animuson: Back when I was very active until last month the community seemed pretty quick to get rid of spam. All it took was one flag for experienced users who don't read all questions to pile on and rid the site of spammy content. The real issue IMO was what I complained about in the chat over 2 months ago: https://chat.stackexchange.com/rooms/16081/the-incubator - If you go through my list of flags, untold numbers of them never made it to a moderator. Which, to me, means you're closing a site because lack of community flagging, whereas the actual problem is lack of mods reading them.

(And to reiterate, I'd happily step in as a mod at the side of a few other long timers if not closing the site is still an option. The only thing is, I can't commit to be on here multiple times per day, due to parental duties.)

@Denis As I explained on SmallChess' post, this is a *community moderated* site. The community itself can destroy spam with 6 spam flags, just as it can close a question with 5 close votes. Sure, a moderator can do that with a single button press, but that's not what diamond moderators exist for. The regular users should be doing as much of this moderation as possible, with moderators stepping in as little as possible to handle the edge cases. Depending entirely on a moderator to do *all of the work* is a sign of a failing community - especially when that moderator inevitably burns out.

@DenisdeBernardy Congratulations on your new child! I was hoping we could stay in touch, so I emailed you at your mesoconcepts sites. I understand you're busy (and happy ... and sleep-deprived...!) so just reply whenever you have a few minutes. Thanks!

"Our mods should have done something" is exactly the kind of thinking that dooms a site to failure. A site should *not* be dependent on the moderators doing all of the clean-up work and decision making. It should be dependent on its users doing the majority of the work and moderators only stepping in to handle edge cases. But those users don't seem to exist here - either they just don't want to do it or they've all left. Aside: Nick was actually replaced a while ago, but for some reason was just never removed as moderator.
